text:
We have our very own Steve Blank
and Joe Felter joining us today to discuss the origins of
hacking for defense, a course

that many of you have taken
or have expressed interest in taking. How many of you have
taken hacking for defense?

Ooh. Ooh. A whole room of candidates. Wow OK, this will
be interesting.

Actually, in fact, I
remember it wasn't too long ago that you guys were getting
the course off the ground

since I was on
campus back in 2016. And also, I was
working on getting this speaker series
Silicon Valley

and the US government
off the ground. And just we talked about
having the speaker series also

be an introduction to students
who want to take a three to four unit course, like
hacking for defense, so it's been incredible to
see how these efforts have

evolved since then. Steve, why don't we
start with-- can you just describe to us what
is hacking for defense?

It's magic. So hacking for defense is a
way for Stanford students,

and now students in 60
some odd universities, couple of countries, to actually
get their hands on real DOD

and potentially IC problems. And actually work on them with
teams of three to five students.

And deeply understand
the problem by getting on the building. Building what we call
minimum viable products

for potential
solutions, putting them in front of stakeholders
and warfighters, et cetera using a methodology
called the Lean method

that we've teach
elsewhere at Stanford and we'll talk more about it. But it's, basically,
a experiential,

hands on class for real world
problems in national security. Joe, anything you
would add to that?

Right on. I'll get on the next one. So maybe we could talk about
origins for hacking for defense. How did it get started?

Why did you want to put it
together in the first place? I'm interested in hearing
Joe's version of the story. Well, you were there,
and actually you

were nearby as well, Ernestine. But this is back
in 2015, actually.

How'd it go for-- actually, how it got started
I think a group of people were patriots and cared
about national security, who

cared about finding
opportunities to get our best and brightest involved in really
important national security challenges.

I had been in the military for
20 plus years in special forces. I'll try to do the
quick one because I

know this class is
only so long, but I had started a
company called BMNT when I got out of the military
and brought in a Colonel, Pete

Newell, who was legendary in
the military, brigade commander in Iraq, Silver
Star winner, and ran

what's called the army's
rapid equipping force. But we had started
something called hack defense, which was
going to be just more

traditional hackathon where we
bring students and people in to work on a defense-sponsored
challenge, like for a day.

But then whom you know,
remember John Kuhn, a former-- one of our special
special operators

that I was connected to when
I was still in the military before he came-- Tall guy. --to Stanford. Yeah so he came to Stanford,
was taking Steve's famous Lean

LaunchPad class and
was really inspired as people that
take Steve's class. But I stayed in touch with him.

And he told me about Steve
Blank and how amazing his-- he was actually working on
what was a de facto confidence

problem in the Lean
LaunchPad program. But he was interested in
introducing me to Steve and Pete

Newell, whom we all knew. And we went down to BMC
and we started talking.

Steve Blank talked
about his approach, and then Pete Nolte shared
some of his experiences

in the rapid equipping
force from the army in Iraq and Afghanistan. And I had spent a lot of time
in Iraq and Afghanistan, too.

But long story short,
it was, kind of, inspirational to well let's riff
on Steve's very successful Lean

LaunchPad class, and let's
get students the chance to get involved in solving
national security challenges. And we set off, this
is in 2015, to rewrite

Steve's educators
guide and tailor it to a hacking for defense model
where the big differences was

students are going to be working
on defense and intelligence community challenges. So we piloted the class.

I know you're giving me the
I got more questions look. But pilot the first
class, and we thought, who's going to take this class.

This is Stanford. This is the nickname
get rich you. And we know why they take
Steve's Lean LaunchPad class because they
literally get rich doing it.

They wanna get rich, yeah. And many of them have but
who would take our class? Well, turns out we had
three extra applicants as we had space that
students, at a minimum,

wanted to work on
tough challenges. All the engineers here. But we tapped into what we
think is a strain of patriotism,

a sense of wanting to serve. Whether-- They may not want to join the
military or a three letter agency or the
government, but they

want to lend their
incredible Stanford intellect to work on
problems that really matter and have impact. And we tapped into that.

Very successful first year. And then as working
with Steve, it's nothing you always
have to scale.

So we started to scale it. Got some resources from the
Office of Naval Research

and pushed it out to
more universities. Now it's in multiple countries. And I think we have a--

why do you want to
do this in Sweden? Why would you want to do this? Why we did it, of
course, because we

need to use the brilliant
minds of students to solve [INAUDIBLE] problems. All right. That's-- we're trying
to evangelize it.

So it's been a great ride
and it's still going, but I'll riff some more. Everything Steve touches has to
go national or international.

It was very interesting. And the fact was, well, why
don't we create a class? It's kind of a Stanford thing. Yeah, sure.

Why don't we do a different
whiteboard whiteboard. It'll look like this. And we'll take this piece and-- but they had this great class
called hack for defense.

And like a great entrepreneur,
yeah, great artists steal.

I said, well, why don't you
just add the word hacking. And of course, everybody hated
the name hacking for defense. No, we're not hacking,
we're not breaking, I said,

but no one will forget the name. And of course, no one
has forgotten the name. And I should tell him the story
about the Department at MS&E

said, there is no
way we're putting the title of a class
called hacking for anything

on our formal whatever. And then we got Bill
Perry to say, well, what a great name that is.

And of course, Bill Perry
was a ex-secretary of Defense who was in the MS&E Department. And when he waved his magic
wand across our class, what

you got him to do,
Joe, it became magic. So, back to you. Yeah. And that's great. So, Steve, maybe dive
into what exactly

is Lean startup Lean
LaunchPad methodology, and why does this work for addressing
national security needs?

So this was the
inference I was talking about what Pete discovered
on the battlefield for rapid equipping.

And I discovered, just
doing eight startups in Silicon Valley,
is that on day one,

the problem, if you're smart,
and by definition, you all are. They're smarter you are,
the harder it is not

to believe your own BS. Meaning you think you not only
understand the problem you--

that's you typically
implicitly think you understand the
problem, and you dive right into building the solution.

And then you think, all I need
to do is get the right team, raise some money. Here are the PowerPoint slides. Build the solution.

And the biggest problem
I'm going to have is the room big enough to
hold the bags of money that are going to come. And the answer is very rarely.

And where you go all the
way wrong is on day one, you had a series of
assumptions, guesses.

And at Stanford, because
we pay a lot of money to allow you to use
the word hypotheses. And so we have a series
of untested hypotheses

about, in the commercial world,
customers and distribution channel and pricing, et cetera. In the DOD, we have a set of
assumptions about stakeholders

and warfighters
and colors of money and how do we get to deployment
and scale, et cetera, all those are
hypotheses on day one.

And unless you've truly
done this multiple times, you're just, kind of, guessing. And so the whole Lean method,
back to answering your question,

is how do we rapidly turn
those hypotheses into facts? That is, on day
one any new venture
is a faith-based enterprise. It's a religious activity. It's a big idea. All you have is religion.

But you literally need that
to start but you rapidly want to translate that into
evidence-based, fact-based

decisions. And so how you do that is you
get it out of the building. Step one, using a process
called customer development.

You build what we call
minimum viable products. That is not just
prototypes of the product,

but they could be of
pricing, of outcomes, of screenshots, of
wireframes, of something.

And they're called MVPs,
minimum viable products. And a radical notion, which
never even existed in the 20th

century, is you're
allowed to pivot. And a pivot is a fancy word
for you're allowed to change

your mind without getting
fired, which, believe it or not, did not exist in
the 20th century. And in the DOD, the
equivalent is no, you

don't start with requirements,
you start with problems. Because if you know all
you have are assumptions,

they're going to change. A pivot says, when I
have enough evidence that my initial
assumption is wrong,

I'm allowed to say we have
enough evidence to change either the features of the product
or how we're funding it,

or pricing, or who
the stakeholders are, or who the saboteurs
are, et cetera. And so those are the kind
of components of Lean.

Customer development, get
it out of the building, test assumptions. Build the product
iteratively and incrementally

with MVPs literally weekly
in a class or as fast as you can in the real world.

And then we use something called
the business model or mission model canvas to keep track
of all the components we're

trying to test. Who are the stakeholders? What's mission achievement
or what's revenue

in the commercial
world, et cetera. It's not a very
complicated set of things, it's just a framework.

And by the way, it's not the
framework, it's a framework. And if you got a better
one, feel free to use it.

No one is going to
tell you you have to except if you take the class. But the rest is just a way to
cut down all this cruft that

went on in the 20th century
of flailing and going out of business because you
made some dumb assumptions,

mostly because you believed
that what was in your head was correct. Does that answer your question? Yeah.

Yeah. So what are some-- You took the class, right? Actually, I haven't
taken the class. You haven't the class. [INAUDIBLE]

I missed the opportunity. Oh, wait a minute. Now you're going to
co-- wait a minute, you're going to co-teach
the class with us. Well, we'll see, we'll see.

I think you have lots of
qualified instructors. No. No wait a minute. Don't you think they'll
be recruiting here? For sure. All right.

But-- so what are some of
the problem statements that you've sourced from DOD
IC and what are some--

Let me just riff on
one thing from Steve because he mentioned the
business model canvas and the mission model canvas.

Two big shifts, and there
may be some other minor ones, but in the business
world, I'm speaking in front of the guy
who developed it,

but success is measured in
profit in the business world. But in the types of
problems we're addressing,

it's measured in mission
achievement and impact. So we had to tweak the
business model canvas to the mission model canvas.

And one thing that's important,
those of you in the military and government know this. In the military and
government agencies,

the person using
the product isn't the person buying the product. In the military, you've got this
acquisitions and requirements

system where someone
else-- you're on a mine-- you're on
a path in Afghanistan with a mine detector that is
saving or losing your life

and someone else decided
which is a good one and bought it for you. You had no impact on it. So those are two
big distinctions.

But yeah, problem
is-- there's a range. We went from DOD, across
the services, to-- across--

with Steve here and others, we
were supporting the intelligence community a lot. I mean, it's just-- and now
with 60 plus universities doing,

it's a whole range. What are some of the problems,
some of the solutions? Can I tell their
business model-- Please. --mission models to
do the Canvas story?

Got to. So any of you who've seen the
Osterwalder's business model canvas? Any who've seen it?

All of you should probably
look at it online. It's basically the
framework we use. It's a single piece
of paper that--

anybody ever hear of
writing a business plan? It's basically how
to write a business plan in a single piece of paper
that's what I love about it.

It tells you all
the important things you ought to be thinking about
before you write the plan. Who are the customers,
what's the channel whatever.

And the famous book
that Osterwalder wrote was something called
Business Model Generation. And why I love it?

It's all pictures, so
I could understand it. It's like nice pictures
to describe one picture.

And it truly is
worth looking at. Well, I'm telling you the story
because that was, kind of, one of the three components of
the commercial class called

Lean startup. And so we like to use
this in the-- actually, before the class, I used inside
the intelligence community.

And of course, at the end of
the first class, the guy who ended up teaching
it and scaling it

with me inside this agency,
Matt, calls up and said, Steve one of the boxes in
the business model Canvas

says revenue and profit. And he said, well, if we have
that, we're all going to jail. This is kind of a great diagram
but doesn't quite match,

as Joe said, what actually
happens in the DOD and IC? Some of these things are--
it says customers and yeah,

they're, kind of,
customers, but they're also stakeholders and war fighters
and saboteurs and contractors. And so is there any
way we can modify it?

And I go, well, I
didn't write it, but my friend
Alexander Osterwalder. And I thought oh,
we're entrepreneurs.

So me and Matt, from this
agency, and Pete Newell get on the phone to Osterwalder.

And within an hour
and a half, we created an entirely new canvas
called the mission model canvas, which had
from about 20 feet,

looks identical to
business model Canvas, but is oriented for
DOD, IC and nonprofits. And you look at it and
you go, why, of course,

it was designed for us, but
literally it's how we move. Didn't work? OK. Pivoted.

Oh, we didn't create it? Let's call the guy who did
create it and worked with him and boom, boom boom. And that's how we got the--

A little more call--
one of those calls was on Super Bowl
Sunday about half time, and Pete and I were at my house.

I'm sorry you were there too. We may have had a couple
beverages at that point, but we were being very creative
and it turned out well,

so I'll just leave it at that. And Alex who was in
Switzerland in the night. Yeah, it was-- The middle of the night I
called him up and said-- And Steve was at his palatial
ranch where some of you

have been to. Are there other
tools and frameworks that are key to the
course that students take,

or other kind of things that are
different from Lean launchpad?

Not-- well what's different
about this class at Stanford and the Lean
Launchpad is not much.

But behind this class nationally
is a whole set of machinery that you don't see
unless you're trying

to start a national program. And that is how the
problems are sourced. Between Joe and Jeff Decker
and Pete Newell and I,

we have some-- enough contacts in
the DOD IC that I guess we could get
our own problem

sets from multiple people. But Pete and Joe
and BMMT stood up a nonprofit called the
Common Mission Project

that actually sources problems
from across the DOD and IC and doles them out to
these 60 universities.

That's a massive effort
that you don't see. It's, kind of, all the
background on a play. All you see are the actors on
the front, and it looks easy,

but there's people doing
lighting and stage direction and there's musicians
and whatever, those are all the moving parts.

How do you pick the problems? How do we pick the problems? You get like lots and lots of
problem statements from DODIC.

How do you pick them? Yeah, so at the end of the
day, the students pick them. But you mean how
are they selected? Oh, I'm sorry.

Yes, selected. Yeah. Yeah. Yeah. They have to be scoped to lend
themselves to classroom work.

They need to have
impact, and they need to be problems, not solutions. And that's a big, big thing.

A lot of sponsors,
if you will, and we can talk about that later,
will come with almost like a solution. And they just want to
have someone go down

the road to get a better-- refine that solution. But they have to
be problems, they have to be very
open-ended like that

to lend themselves to let you
know Steve's methodology go to work and the
discovery process. But we want them to be, scoped,
relevant, important, impactful,

and get students inspired. They're going to work
many, many, many hours throughout the quarter and
some of them well beyond that.

It has to inspire students. They've got to be
problems that matter. Yeah so what are
some of the problems?

Well, they also have
to be unclassified. Yeah. And that's a challenge. And they have to
be scrubbed down. And actually, last
year, we got one

from In-Q-Tel that
was so scrubbed down it was unintelligible. They had a data fusion problem
that they actually translated

into an F1 racing team. And the students, nor I, could
figure out what the heck.

So we finally got
them to write it in English that was
still unclassified. But in the first class,
the one we still talk about

was a team I didn't
even want to let in. You didn't let them in
the class [INAUDIBLE]. Yeah, because it wasn't a
problem we got, it was one

they were wanted to work
on, which we we'll now do every once in a while. If you have your own you think
there's a problem to solve.

It was a bunch of
engineers here. What did they know? Their NRO had these
billion-dollar battlestar

galacticas for synthetic
aperture radar satellites that I had known and had
been in space for decades.

And these engineers came
in with the gall to say, well, we could replace
those with CubeSats.

It was Capella space
for those of you who know about
starting in our class. Capella space, basically,
if not obsoleted,

certainly complements and led
the whole synthetic aperture radar CubeSat thing.

Which is just a fancy way to
say it was a piece of disruptive technology that observed that
all the expensive stuff that

the DOD had been
building with primes, can now be both
miniaturized number one, but cost reduced by like
a factor of 100 or 1,000,

which was not just
better, but game changing. And now there are multiple
SAR instances in space.

Another one, later
on, was Vannevar labs. Nini and the rest of
her-- those of you who know Vannevar, that
had just had a $90 million

A around or something. Which was funny, is
because they're essentially an OSINT tool but here I was
in a building a month ago

in about three groups,
stand up and said, and from our Vancouver labs. And I went, what? And it turns out
they're in more places

than I think they either
know or will admit. And so I don't know Joe. Who else? Those are great.

I like the Agrippa story, how
[INAUDIBLE] contested logistics in Indo-Pacific And then
they're off to the races now.

Oh, can we talk about
the fish reel story? Do you remember this the
Navy SEAL diving CO2 thing?

Do you want me to tell it or-- You tell it. So this was a team of
freshmen-- and stop me, Joe,

if I get this wrong. But it was a great example
of how the class works. We got a problem from the
medical director of SEAL Team

something that said, look, our
divers are spending way too much time underwater, and they have
symptoms of carbon dioxide

poisoning or too much exposure. We just need a simple sensor. He thought he had a
problem, give us a solution.

And naively, we went OK, sure. And the team formed
around that problem. And they had a medical device
person and they had whatever.

And they had coaches
in that domain. And so the first thing they do--

hope methodology-- the class,
get out of the building, talk to the SEALs. Which, by the way, I don't
even know what a SEAL was.

I think they were first
going to go to the zoo. But instead, they found the
SEALs and they told them, hey,

this is what the
medical director wants.  Where would you like
this little sensor?

And what do you think
their answer was? At the bottom of the ocean. Well, why?

Well, they were smart. What would the
medical director do if they saw they were taking
too much carbon dioxide?
What would they do? Pull them out. Pull them out. Well you're a SEAL. You don't want to be pulled out.

But here is the
magic of the class. Because this is what
we taught the team. They said, well, OK, you
don't want the device,

but why are you exposed to
carbon dioxide more than-- oh, our missions are lasting
much longer underwater
than they're supposed to. Again, asking why. Well, why is that? Well, we get lost.

What do you mean, you get lost. You're in a SEAL
delivery vehicle. How hard is this? Well, there's a lot
of metal sometimes

in places where we're going. Well, don't you have GPS? Well, no, our buoy
only goes so high.

Well, oh, well, now they
had a much different problem definition, which wasn't CO2.

It was time to mission. And two is it was
like, no, they didn't have an accurate
navigation device

in magnetically
challenged areas. So they qualified as divers
in the Stanford swimming

pool, the entire
team, and developed a CO2 deployable antenna
that got deployed

as a workaround
for this SEALs team that they used in
a couple missions. These were freshmen.

Freshmen. 10 weeks. 10 weeks. So that was when
we thought perhaps we're on to something
in this class.

Now, we weren't trying to
replace a SEAL delivery vehicle, and they were supposed to be
a new version or whatever, and gosh knows what happened.

And people went oh, you can't
do that or blah, blah, blah. But it was a great
example of everybody

thought it was pretty simple. It just needed a CO2 meter. But the minute you got out
and talked to the warfighter,

well, that was just a
symptom of-- and by the way, when we went back to
the medical director, he said, well, they
never told me that.

Well, he never asked them. All right. Sorry for the-- Yeah no, I think you actually
touch upon a good point,

that we've talked about in this
class, where the buyer is so far removed from the end user.

And how do you think, as
you're curating these problem statements, finding
solutions, how do you

find that balance between-- are the problem statements
coming mostly from the buyers and the students
are then going out

and talking to the end users? Or how are you
balancing all that? I mean, it's a mix of sponsors.

Oftentimes, our students
they-- we will start out working with a problem sponsor
and realize the problem

is someplace very different
and leave the sponsor behind. That's not the problem. Here's the real problem.

That's a symptom of
a problem, perhaps. So Steve's methodology,
it does it. You find out oftentimes
what you think

is the problem is a symptom
and you do your discovery, get out of the building. You talk to enough
people and you realize,

here's the real
root of the problem. And by the way, this is
incredibly hard for all of you.

The reason why it's
not technically hard, there's no math involved,
but to be honest,

it's a lot easier to do if
you're dumb because you'll go assume you don't
know the answer.

The smarter you are,
the more difficult it is to do this
methodology seriously. Because, by definition,
you're at Stanford.

You are some of the smartest
people in the world. So how hard could this
be to figure it out? The problem is, it's very rare
that you could pre-compute

the needs of potential customers
and warfighters and stakeholders and understand the motives of
saboteurs and requirements, et

cetera, from sitting
inside your room. Possible but improbable. But again, it's a mindset thing.

And so if you do this
back off and say-- and in fact, the way I usually
approach very smart people

is humor me. Let's assume you're right. Just go out and
talk to 10 people. And if they agree with you,
you get an A in the class.

Your team's done. I've yet to see
someone win that bet. Ever. And again, it's not that you
can't precompute a lot of stuff,

but these problems
are, as Joe said, almost every time
the problem is given

and we don't even know
how it's going to end up, is always a symptom of
something much more interesting. Some requirements
writers somewhere else

had it right two years ago
but the world has changed. No one would have pre-computed
the Houthis shooting drones

at us, and us shooting SM-3s
back in $20,000 drones. That just wasn't-- there was no
way someone could have figured

that out. So that's why the
methodology works. It just assumes that
you're getting out

and you're doing
one of three things with a assumption, a guess. You're validating it. Hey, I was right, Steve.

See. But most often gee
invalidating that assumption.

Or, kind of, half the time,
I'm modifying the assumption. I got some new facts. It's kind of true,
but maybe it's

over here or somewhere else. I forgot what your question was. Yeah no. So you alluded to the fact
that problem statements have

shifted over the years as well. I assume given
changes geopolitically

as well, what have you seen
over the years in terms of how those problem
statements have changed? What are some like
recent problem statements

that have emerged just
given recent conflicts? When we developed
the class, we were just-- had gone through
just over a decade

of the war on terror of
the IED fight of soldiers getting blown up. And so a lot of the problems
reflected that experience.

But we're shifting, great,
great power competition, high intensity major power war.

But the approach hasn't changed. You still, using
this methodology, it's-- the problems may
change, but you go out and talk

to people and you iterate. So yeah, the challenge
of the Defense Department and the intelligence community
are facing are shifting.

You can't say the war on
terror-- the enemy gets a vote. We still have to
combat terrorism.

But we are looking
at peer competitors. Steve and I teach a class
along with Eric Vollmer, who's back there, another
course instructor

here called technology
innovation and great power competition, where
we're really looking at tech-informed
solutions to some of the challenges of
great power competition.

But those challenges
are shifting but the only thing we've been
perfectly effective at it's

not predicting the next war. So we think we may
know the next wars, we're thinking Taiwan
Strait somewhere else,

but we're probably
dead wrong again. So we don't have the
luxury of narrowing

our lane of the
problems we look at, but we definitely are expanding
it from when we started the course to include a lot more
of the traditional major power

war and the problems
associated with that. So, Joe, you just reminded
me about the shift from IED--

I'd say if I had to pick a major
shift, it's from IEDs to drones. Yeah. There's a-- but there
is a great IED story.

Do you remember there
was a problem that was how do we now train Iraqi
IED folks from all the knowledge

the US IED folks had. And we had a team who
was trying to understand, what does an IED explosive
ordnance disposal team actually
do. And they came in Class II-- Class I. Do you remember this? Yeah. [MUMBLING]

We should have a
photo [INAUDIBLE]. Class II bloviating, bloviating. That's usually my job, yeah,
blah, blah, blah, blah, blah.

And, finally, I
said, what the heck do you know about IED disposal? These are just
PowerPoint slides.
Have you put on an IED suit? This is to the team. No where would we get that.

Turns out there's an FBI
training course in Oakland. Well, the next week, they
get us videos of them.

Remember walking downstairs
carrying the stuff fully decked out in IED.

Oh, they had a much different
appreciation of what-- They went from zero to hero. The week before,
they were the zeros.

They were-- Well, there was another example. And, again, this
is just giving you an example but experiential
means in this class.
Anybody know what BUD/S is? BUD/S training. What is it?

What is it. Kind of day at the
beach or what is it? What is it? It's a lot of physical stuff.

It's a lot of
underwater testing. Great. Absolutely. It's not a day at the beach.

It's pretty miserable. Probably some of
the toughest, hazing ritual you could get in a class.

And so one of the

Yeah, yeah. And it all started with the
Lean startup methodology. Well, Lean startup
just simply came

from me being an
entrepreneur for 21 years. And then-- how many of
you have done a startup

or been involved in one? In a startup, if you're
having big thoughts, I'm going to fire you.

Your thoughts are
focused on a narrow beam, maybe about your
market, but certainly for survival of your company.

It wasn't until I got to
retire that I actually started to think about
the nature of innovation and entrepreneurship,
and how we were

being told to build
startups, which were you're simply a smaller version
of a large company. That was the implicit mantra in
the 20th century to startups.

Large companies write business
plans, you write them, they write five year
plans, you write them. They hire sales, marketing,
and Biz Dev on day one,

you do that too. And by the way,
everybody executes via what's called waterfall
methodology alpha test,

beta test, first customer ship. Assume everything works. That was the methodology. There was no other
language, no other toolset,

no other thoughts. There wasn't even a way to
describe anything different. And it was only because I
had time to actually think

about the nature of
what we were doing, and why it didn't actually match
what the successful patterns

of entrepreneurs were. I didn't invent anything. I simply-- how they
described how Michelangelo

did a sculpture, he
didn't do a sculpture, he just removed the
stone around it. And what I did was simply
removed all the noise

around what best
practices were already there and just
gave it a language. Does that make sense? Yeah.
